sols_html:
Differentiating \(\displaystyle f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}\) gives

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = \frac{6x^{-2/5}}{5} + \frac{-6x^{-7/5}}{5} = \frac{6x^{-7/5}}{5}(x-1)\).

Thus the critical numbers are \(x=1\) and \(x=0\) (notice here our derivative and our function are both undefined). So we check the intervals \(\displaystyle (-\infty,0),(0,1),(1,\infty)\) individually.

Case 1

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (-\infty,0)\end{aligned}\]

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say \(x = -1\), which gives a value of \(12/5 > 0\). Thus the function is increasing on this interval.

Case 2

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (0,1)\end{aligned}\]

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say \(x = 1/2\), which gives a value of \(6\cdot 2^{7/5}/5(-1/2) < 0\). Thus the function is decreasing on this interval.

Case 3

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (1,\infty)\end{aligned}\]

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say \(x = 2\), which gives a value of \(6\cdot 2^{-7/5}/5 > 0\). Thus the function is increasing on this interval.

Summary

Overall, the function in increasing on \((-\infty, 0) \cup (1, \infty)\) and decreasing on \(\displaystyle (0, 1)\).
